instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
I seem to a pile of insane faults.
I got a nasty <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in, Did allot to get it posting, and then found it wouldnt display or boot if the trackpad cable was plugged in, It just seems to sit with backlight on but nothing else.

Tried known good parts, inspected the board, Brushed <CHIP>U4830</CHIP> and it was that corroded it fell off the board. 
Fixed the damage replacing <CHIP>U4830</CHIP> and <CHIP>U4820</CHIP> for good measure, and fixed all the damaged traces and Via's around the area. checked diode mode in  most areas. However the fault still remains.

Now for the strange part. If i hotplug the trackpad after post it all works fine, displays, boots and the trackpad  and keyboard work perfectly.
Ive put a good couple of hours into this one now and im starting to loose my mind.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42397"]Did you change J4802?[/QUOTE]

I have not, Do you believe there could be corrosion under it causing problems? 
j4802  looks perfect under the microscope, and diode mode readings are the same as a known good board.
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
Okay, Ive changed J4802 now. No change. 
Ive noticed something odd. When the TPAD is plugged in <RESISTOR>R4913</RESISTOR> is lower than a known good (2.4V rather than 3v3)

When hotplugged straight after post all works well, and the Trackpad hardware is recognised under the SPI section of system report. Im really struggling to understand why this board will not work! :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U4810</CHIP>, let see if helps.
In normal condition, can you access boot menu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 42616"]Change <CHIP>U4810</CHIP>, let see if helps.
In normal condition, can you access boot menu?[/QUOTE]

I changed <CHIP>U4810</CHIP> and redid <CHIP>U4820</CHIP> again just to be sure. 
No in normal condition you cannot access boot menue, Just a blank black display, No USB activity, Wont read internal SSD.ect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
"When the TPAD is plugged in <RESISTOR>R4913</RESISTOR> is lower than a known good (2.4V rather than 3v3)"
Do you get 3.4V on both pins?
Check pin8/<CHIP>U4910</CHIP> too.

"Change <CHIP>U4810</CHIP>, let see if helps."
My mistake, I was looking other schematic.
I should write <CHIP>U4910</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message: [USER="468"]ALB-Repairs[/USER] Did you ever solve this? I have the exact same issue. every detail: no video. backlight only. but boots normally and has video without trackpad connected. 2.4V on both sides of <RESISTOR>R4913</RESISTOR> with trackpad plugged in. 3.3V with trackpad unplugged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
Did you try known good trackpad flex/board?

<SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_IF_EN_CONN</SIGNAL> should be high once entered into OSX; itb stays low (0V) before.

<SIGNAL>TPAD_VBUS_EN</SIGNAL> should be high before accesing OSX; i.e. boot menu.
It should drop once OSX is started.
If file vault is enabled, <SIGNAL>TPAD_VBUS_EN</SIGNAL> is still enabled on the password screen; no <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI_IF_EN_CONN</SIGNAL> yet, in such case.

Check <CHIP>U4910</CHIP> inputs and outputs, to decide if works correctly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
Holy thread revival.
I figured it out a while ago, there was a resistor for SPI (maybe a pullup) that looked okay, but the pad underneath was half missing. I cannot remember which resistor, i only figured it out by deciding to replace all components related to trackpad SPI
Thanks though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
An issue on SPI bus shouldn't stop to access boot menu.
Before enter to OSX, trackpad and keyboard work through USB.
I saw one case where USB enable from PCH was sorted to ground; trackpad only worked once logged into OSX.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No display/USB when TPAD plugged in
threads.message:
Im not sure how correct you are, as part of diagnosis i lifted the USB lines from the trackpad connector. I did this to try and disable USB, to see if the black screening was resolved, but even without the USB lines it still black screened.
If memory serves correctly it was corrosion on a pad under <RESISTOR>R1618</RESISTOR>, as i said, i repaired this months ago, and it was to do with the SPI! (I may have got the exact resistor wrong, but it was certainly in that area)
